author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: World cred, Maine bred blues
text:
World cred, Maine bred blues Oct 13, 2015 Memphis Lightning 
Rockland — The weekly Monday Night Blues series continues Oct. 26 with a 7 p.m. show by Memphis Lightning in the upstairs music room of Time Out Pub, 275 Main St. Admission at the door will be $10. 
Well-seasoned veterans and the future of the blues meet in Maine’s Memphis Lightning, a trio that delivers energetic blues, rock ‘n’ roll, American roots music and country. As the eldest statesman, bass player Billy Ray has laid down the bottom end for the Piners and the late, great Eddie Kirkland. On the other end of the age spectrum is lead guitarist Jimmy Jay, who was riding shotgun with Kirkland at age 12. Grammy-nominated international touring and recording artist J.D. Jukejoint plays the drums, and occasionally the guit-fiddle, providing the backbone of Memphis Lightning. 
Upcoming in the weekly series are: Nov. 2, Bobby Messano ($10); Nov. 9, Slam Allen Band ($10); Nov. 16, Roberto Morbioli ($10); and Nov. 23, John Primer ($15). All shows are subject to change. For more information, visit northatlanticbluesfestival.com and click on the Time Out Blues link; call 596-6055 or email bluesman@midcoast.com.
